info.author: Martijn Faassen
info.description:
sa_mysql_dt
***********

MySQL, unlike for instance, PostgreSQL, doesn't support datetime
columns with a sub-second granularity. This means that it is not
possible to distinguish between two datetimes that were generated in
the same second.

This can however be very useful. This package defines a new field type
for SQLAlchemy that should be a drop-in replacement for the standard
SQLAlchemy DateTime. It stores its information in a Numeric column to
enable sub-second granularity. 

It's probably also not properly timezone aware.

To use it in a SQLAlchemy table definition as a column type, import it
instead of SQLAlchemy's version::

  >>> from sa_mysql_dt import DateTime

CHANGES
*******

0.1.2 (2010-11-15)
==================

- Nothing changed yet.


0.1.1 (2010-11-15)
==================

* Bugfix release; somehow CHANGES.txt wasn't included.

0.1 (2010-11-15)
================

* Initial public release.

Download
********
info.name: sa_mysql_dt
info.summary: Alternative implementation of DateTime column for MySQL.
info.html_description:
sa_mysql_dt

MySQL, unlike for instance, PostgreSQL, doesn’t support datetime columns with a sub-second granularity. This means that it is not possible to distinguish between two datetimes that were generated in the same second.

This can however be very useful. This package defines a new field type for SQLAlchemy that should be a drop-in replacement for the standard SQLAlchemy DateTime. It stores its information in a Numeric column to enable sub-second granularity.

It’s probably also not properly timezone aware.

To use it in a SQLAlchemy table definition as a column type, import it instead of SQLAlchemy’s version:

>>> from sa_mysql_dt import DateTime

CHANGES

0.1.2 (2010-11-15)

  • Nothing changed yet.

0.1.1 (2010-11-15)

  • Bugfix release; somehow CHANGES.txt wasn’t included.
